body.p: We have developed a series of logging requirements for hosting platforms, such as virtualised and/or containered compute with associated supporting services such as database and queuing services at different maturity tiers in order to support defenisve cyber security, such as detecting breaches.
Log Collection Principle(s): 1, 2
User directory services must create and forward Authentication and Authorisation events from the directory service itself.

User directories within hosting environments can be rich and diverse, such technologies include:
Active Directory (AD)
Azure Active Directory
OpenLDAP
Amazon Web Services (Accounts and Incognito)
Okta
Auth0
Github.com (acting as an identity provider)
(acting as an identity provider)
Local user stores within operating systems

These event types must be logged and forwarded:
Account creation
Account lockout
Account reinstatement
Account authentication failures
Account authentication successes after 1 or more failures
Account password changes
Group membership addition / deletion (in particular, any group that gives admin access)
Group creation
Privilege modification for users (for example, role delegation through AWS IAM)
Multi-factor authentication state, such as:
Enabled
Disabled
Reset/rotation
Recovery method used
Log Collection Principle(s): 1, 2, 6

Bastion/jump boxes that act as a management consolidation route and should be highly auditable therefore must create and forward security-related event data:
SSH keypair generation/revocation, including:
Public key
Keypair 'friendly name' / identifier
Account login attempts:
Public key
Username
Log Collection Principle(s): 4

DNS query logs must be created and forwarded:
Client IP address
Query
Query response content including:
Returned record(s) or NXDOMAIN
Authoritative nameserver
Query response code
Zone and/or view identifier (if local zone response and/or multiview)
This remains true for where nodes (for example, servers) may bypass internal DNS services.
Log Collection Principle(s): 5

Where web traffic proxies exist, access logs should be created and forward and must, include the following variables:
Authenticated user name (if applicable)
Client identifiers:
IP address
Reverse lookup client name (if applicable)
HTTP method (for example, CONNECT GET)
Where available, full destination/target URL or SNI value
Connection return status code (for example, 200 or 403)
Size of response
Log Collection Principle(s): 3, 6

Hypervisors manage virtualised compute resources and are entrusted to segregate the same. All instructions to hypervisors should be highly auditable.
Virtual machine creation (including templates)
Identifier(s)
Operating system image information
Virtual machine 'power' events:
Identifier(s)
'Power' on
'Power' off (including restart flag)
Virtual machine deletion
Identifier(s)
Virtual machine resource modification events:
CPU addition/removal
RAM addition/removal
Networking additional/removal
Storage mount/dismount/resize
Log Collection Principle(s): 3, 6

Orchestrators such as Cloud Foundry and Kubernetes create and manage a variety of technology resources to facilitate an application environment.
Resource creation (including templates)
Identifier(s)
Resource type
Operating system image information (if applicable)
Container 'power' events
Identifier(s)
'Power' on
'Power' off (including restart flag)
Resource deletion
Identifier(s)
Resource modification events:
Identifier(s)

topic.title: 7. Allocation of IP address leases from DHCP services

body.p: Log Collection Principle(s): 3, 5

DHCP services must be configured to create and forward the following:
Successful client DHCP requests, including:
Requesting client MAC address
DHCP scope identifier
IP address leased
IP address lease duration
Unsuccessful client DHCP requests, including:
Requesting client MAC address
DHCP scope identifier (if applicable for unsuccessful request)

topic.title: 1. Firewall log data for denied network traffic

body.p: Log Collection Principle(s): 5

All firewall DENY log data must be forwarded.
Client IP address
Firewall/router identifier
Request response code
Request content, including:
IP protocol (for example, ICMP)
Destination/target port
Destination/target IP address
Destination/target hostname address (if reverse lookup performed)
Log Collection Principle(s): 4
Internal domain name spaces must ultimate forward, in an RFC5936 (DNS Zone Transfer Protocol (AXFR) compatible format including all information described in the RFC.

topic.title: 3. DHCP scopes (and the functional segmentation of each)

body.p: Log Collection Principle(s): 5
Machine-readable DHCP scope exports (and surrounding metadata/description of the purpose of each scope) must be created and forwarded.
Log Collection Principle(s): 6
Security log data (as defined by the vendor) must be created and forwarded.

topic.title: 5. Security-related logs for all Windows-based end-user devices

body.p: Log Collection Principle(s): 6
Security-related logs, as defined by NCSC's Logging Made Easy template, from all end-user devices operating a Microsoft Windows operating system must be created and forwarded.
Log Collection Principle(s): 1, 2, 3, 6

Where a mobile device management solution is used and end-user devices register/enrol and de-register/de-enrol with it, enrollment data should be created in and forwarded.
Enrolment or un-enrolment event type
End-user device identifier(s), such as client IP address and/or MAC address and/or assigned DHCP name
End-user account name (if applicable)
Log Collection Principle(s): 3, 5

Where VPN services are in use, connection-related log data must be created and forwarded.
Success or unsuccess status
User/certificate identifier
Client IP address
Concentrator identifier
Log Collection Principle(s): 1, 2, 3, 6

Continuous integration and continuous deployment pipelines obey instructions to manage hosting environments and are a privileged position to oversee all tenant resources, they must be highly auditable to clarify activity and attribute the same.
Source identifier(s)
User(s)
Repository
Activity events
Resource creation
Resource destruction
